header.title: Jeremy Corbyn OUT: Who could replace Jeremy Corbyn as Labour leader if he’s axed?
header.subtitle: LABOUR leader Jeremy Corbyn has a core of hardline supporters but calls for him to step down have grown dramatically over the past year. So who might replace him?
header.postText: Quizzed last month on whether he’d resign if Labour lost the upcoming election, Jeremy Corbyn refused to answer, simply insisting the party was “not expecting to lose”. But with increasing scrutiny on the Labour leader’s vague Brexit policy, some believe it’d be impossible for him to continue.', 'Here are all the possible candidates, with odds courtesy of Ladbrokes.', 'The shadow Brexit secretary, 57, was instrumental in forcing Mr Corbyn to accept that Labour would offer a second EU referendum.', 'His tenure as Shadow Brexit Secretary has made him a popular member of the Labour front bench.', 'One July 2019 poll named him favourite to succeed Jeremy Corbyn with 68 percent approval ratings amongst the Labour Grassroots.', 'The 40-year-old committed Corbyn-backer was a protégé of John McDonnell.', 'She has served as shadow business secretary since 2017 and deputised for Mr Corbyn at PMQs earlier this year.', 'Ms Long-Bailey has been mentioned publicly as a potential future leader.', 'Yvette Cooper, 50, a former cabinet minister and leadership contender, has a wealth of experience in frontline British politics.', 'She has won praise for her Commons performances during the Brexit debates and was reportedly being lined up to replace Corbyn after the general election in 2017.', 'She has strong support from MPs and was described as the “Real Leader of the Opposition” by some in Westminster earlier this year.', 'A long-time Corbyn devotee, 39-year-old Angela Rayner Rayner shares her mentor’s radical position on many issues.', 'The shadow education secretary has led the charge against sexism and bullying in the party.', 'Ms Rayner also has a fascinating life story which endears her to voters: she fell pregnant and left school at 16 before rising up the Labour ranks.', 'Ms Piddock, 32, was appointed to a junior shadow role, but has been promised a cabinet-level employment if Labour wins the general election.', 'She was elected MP for North West Durham in 2017 and quickly became a favourite among Corbyn supporters.', 'She was criticised early in her parliamentary tenure for saying she had “absolutely no intention of being friends with any Tories”, calling them “the enemy”.', 'The 59-year-old shadow foreign secretary was sacked from the front bench by Ed Miliband after a poor showing in a by-election and a distasteful tweet.', 'She returned under Mr Corbyn, but has since clashed with his allies over the party’s Brexit policy.', 'However, she has won praise for her performances filling in for Corbyn at PMQs, as well as for her straight-talking media appearances.', 'A Corbyn loyalist, she has emerged as his de facto No. 2 and enjoys strong support from more left-wing party members and, importantly, many of the unions.
header.socioLingVar: Age - Youngsters,Ethnicity - Black,Ethnicity - General,Physical Identity - Physical (and Mental) Impairments

commentThread.commentText: Would definitely not be a man, we're out of fashion at the moment

replies.commentText: I agree, the new Labour leader cannot be a man, but they will surely accept a goat next time. It would do a far better job than Corbyn, and what's more would look the part.

commentThread.commentText: Corbyn could be easily replaced by the toad at the bottom of my garden. It just sits there, says nothing of import, stares vacantly when asked a question and hops away when pressed for an answer.
It has to be Diane Abbott

replies.commentText: Be careful what you wish for. Comrade Corbyn was chosen as leader by some Labour members as a joke. It backfired, and Marxists are running the so called Labour Party now.
It also backfired on the Tories who paid their £3 to join Labour to get Corbyn in charge as they thought he would be shunned.
If we all join Liebore we can pay our fee's and elect her as leader.

commentThread.commentText: What a really miserable selection!!

replies.commentText: Well look at the pool of people they have available to choose from. Not a credible candidate amongst them.
Sir Gallablair will ride in on his white charger. Oh no, not again!

commentThread.commentText: I don't think it will matter for at least a generation. Labour are finished.
Any of them would do a great job of continuing Steptoe's destruction of the Labour Party.
Well there won't be anyone else momentum will only support Corbyn to be the next PM...what we don't need is a far right racist PM like Boris that's for sure
More than likely it would be Marxist McNuggetts.
On a serious note.... nobody in labour is upto the job.
Momentum and McCluskey will choose, so there's not point in worrying about it.
It be another puppet picked by the union bosses - they wield the financial clout in the party.

"Who could replace Jeremy Corbyn as Labour leader if he’s axed?" Surely that should read "when he's axed", which, in the unlikely event that Labour gain a majority at the GE, would be immediately. Labour have form on this; Ken Livingstone did not win the election for his first term as London Mayor but was parachuted in straight after the election and the poor chap that did win was merely cast aside.

The problem is, at the moment, that mostly all the front bench Liebour politicians are a complete shower of brown stuff. If they had a more moderate center left leader like say David Miliband amongst others then they would be much more electable. The far left and right only offer failure. Labour have missed a good chance of getting power by having Corbyn/McDonnell in charge as the Tory government of TM was pretty weak but is getting stronger under Boris. If you remember the 70s and the winter of 76 especially plus no jobs, no money, electricity cuts, rubbish/rats in the streets etc. you won't be voting for Labour on the 12th.

replies.commentText: Yes, 76 eh... far worse than 3 day week land back in  … oh, 73 … Conservative Government !!!

commentThread.commentText: Albert Steptoe, if alive would have been ideal, he could have stood in for Corbyn whilst he was still the leader . Nobody would have noticed the difference.
irrelevant! We all know that Momentum/Trade Union leaders seem to be running the Labour party...with extreme Marxist policies in place.
Same bunch of talentless lame ducks that gave the fortunate Corbyn the ticket. I think Cooper would finish them off so I'll go for her.
Couldn't care less as long as it's not one of those dreadful virtue signaling Labour women who'd have you thrown into prison if you so much as paid them a compliment.
none of the current lot, all rotten to the core and Blair & brown need not apply
The whole Labour front bench needs clearing out. There's not a sane one amongst them.
There is only one person for the job, the man with a proven track record of conning the public:  I present to you that great waffler - Tony Bliar.
the problem is they are all tainted by new labour. it needs to be someone fresh and a proper socialist not the champagne type we have been subjected to. no lawyers, spads or PPE graduates either
The Russian Ambassador to the UK?
Who could replace Corbyn? Now, let me think. I know, take a trip to London zoo and you will have a choice from all the chimpanzees in the monkey house. Mind you, they may be over qualified.
iPad software is utterly useless!
Axed?  Literally? If shown by the BBC, I'm sure most wouldn't complain about the licence fee.
